channel.title: Comments on: Using T-SQL OUTPUT and MERGE To Link Old and New Keys
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: ODELIA MARKIEWICZ
item.dc:creator: ODELIA MARKIEWICZ
item.description: Very nice and informative article here. I also can share my experience in files merging. I mostly use <a href="http://www.altomerge.com/" rel="nofollow">http://www.altomerge.com/</a> and also here http://pdf.ac/5UdGgI to merge my PDFs. I think it also allows you to fill the merged documents.
item.content:encoded: Very nice and informative article here. I also can share my experience in files merging. I mostly use http://www.altomerge.com/ and also here http://pdf.ac/5UdGgI to merge my PDFs. I think it also allows you to fill the merged documents.

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.content:encoded:
Unfortunately I don’t have anything running 2005 to test with, all of my systems are either 2008 R2, 2012, or Azure. It’s also been a while since I thought through this particular issue.

Another option I have used in the past was to create a temp table for the new and old key and select in the old key and a generated new key. Then I do my insert into the target table by joining the source table and this key table, followed by updating the source table from the key table. It’s slightly more moving pieces and if you have IDENTITY columns you have to turn them off and reseed them when you’re done, but it does get the job done.

item.title: By: Daniel
item.dc:creator: Daniel
item.description: Is there a way to rebuild the same merge statement in SQL Server 2005? I need to access the source-id and the inserted-id on a bulk inserting but I also need support for SQL Server 2005.
item.content:encoded: Is there a way to rebuild the same merge statement in SQL Server 2005? I need to access the source-id and the inserted-id on a bulk inserting but I also need support for SQL Server 2005.

item.title: By: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.dc:creator: Eli Weinstock-Herman (tarwn)
item.content:encoded:
Erik: Glad you found it useful ðŸ™‚

Naomi: Thanks, I’ll have to spend some time playing with that. I originally discounted the option since I am doing updates back instead of inserts, but I’ll go back and give it a new look.

item.title: By: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.dc:creator: Naomi Nosonovsky
item.content:encoded:
I am thinking you can even skip the temp table and go straight with the composable DML here

See this tip

item.title: By: Erik
item.dc:creator: Erik
item.content:encoded:
Nice one, Eli.

I spent some hours a while back trying all sorts of conniptions to get OUTPUT to give me columns from the non-updated/inserted table, but failed miserably.

Now you’ve given me the key I needed to do this task! Thank you ten times over.
